channel.title: The Creative Writer's Toolbelt
channel.description:
The Creative Writers Toolbelt is a practical accessible resource for writers who want to improve in the craft.
Each episode explores an aspect of creative writing technique, with examples, allowing you to apply what you learn immediately to your writing.
channel.itunes:subtitle: Practical, accessible advice for the creative writer
channel.itunes:author: Andrew J Chamberlain
channel.itunes:summary:
The Creative Writers Toolbelt is a practical accessible resource for writers who want to improve in the craft.
Each episode explores an aspect of creative writing technique, with examples, allowing you to apply what you learn immediately to your writing.

item.title: Episode 15 - Characters with Edge
item.description: Great books can have ordinary characters plunged into extraordinary situations - but they can also have extraordinary characters who create their own extraordinary situations! Who are these characters? What are they like, and how can we, as writers create them? These characters have what Harry Bingham in his book "How to Write" calls - characters with edge.
item.dc:creator: Andrew J Chamberlain
item.itunes:summary: Great books can have ordinary characters plunged into extraordinary situations - but they can also have extraordinary characters who create their own extraordinary situations! Who are these characters? What are they like, and how can we, as writers create them? These characters have what Harry Bingham in his book "How to Write" calls - characters with edge.
item.itunes:subtitle: Great books can have ordinary characters plunged into extraordinary situations - but they can als...

item.title: Episode 14 - Deeds not words
item.description: It's what your character does, rather than what you say about them, that defines them for the reader. In this episode Andrew talks about how action defines character and gives examples for both heros and villains
item.dc:creator: Andrew J Chamberlain
item.itunes:summary: It's what your character does, rather than what you say about them, that defines them for the reader. In this episode Andrew talks about how action defines character and gives examples for both heros and villains

item.title: Episode 13 - Character Motivation
item.description: Continuing our series on characterisation, in this episode we look at character motivation and why the motivation for the characters in our writing must be: evident to the reader, reasonable and understandable, and must drive the plot.
item.dc:creator: Andrew J Chamberlain
item.itunes:summary: Continuing our series on characterisation, in this episode we look at character motivation and why the motivation for the characters in our writing must be: evident to the reader, reasonable and understandable, and must drive the plot.

item.title: Episode 12 - What three qualities do you need to be a good writer?
item.description: What are the personal qualities you need, not only keep you writing but to help you improve in your craft? Andrew shares his views on why perseverance, humility, and imagination are the fundamental character traits you need to develop as a writer.
item.dc:creator: Andrew J Chamberlain
item.itunes:summary: What are the personal qualities you need, not only keep you writing but to help you improve in your craft? Andrew shares his views on why perseverance, humility, and imagination are the fundamental character traits you need to develop as a writer.
item.itunes:subtitle: What are the personal qualities you need, not only keep you writing but to help you improve in yo...

item.title: Episode 11 - Creating the individual character (part 1)
item.description: In the last episode we looked at character integrity and how this is founded on 1.Believability/plausibility and 2. The character as an individual. In this episode I'm going to start to look at how a character can become an individual, focusing on descriptive markers and character weaknesses.
item.dc:creator: Andrew J Chamberlain

item.title: Episode 10 - Getting to know you! Believability and consistency as the keys to developing character integrity
item.description: This episode introduces the core requirements for good character development: character integrity and individuality. We will look at individuality next time, but in this episode we look at how making a character believable, and keeping them consistent are the keys to successful characterisation.
item.dc:creator: Andrew J Chamberlain
item.itunes:summary: This episode introduces the core requirements for good character development: character integrity and individuality. We will look at individuality next time, but in this episode we look at how making a character believable, and keeping them consistent are the keys to successful characterisation.

item.title: Episode 9 - Get Active! Using the right verbs and the right voice to energise your story
item.description: In this episode I cover two issues, using precise and powerful verbs, and also using the active rather than passive voice to energise and drive your story
item.dc:creator: Andrew J Chamberlain
item.itunes:summary: In this episode I cover two issues, using precise and powerful verbs, and also using the active rather than passive voice to energise and drive your story

item.title: Episode 8 - 'Just in time' storytelling
item.description: Grabbing the reader's attention immediately is a vital part of storytelling. Often writers will start a story too early, or fill the first critical paragraphs with backstory and infodump. In this podcast we explore techniques to make sure your writing grabs the reader right from the first sentence.
item.dc:creator: Andrew J Chamberlain
item.itunes:summary: Grabbing the reader's attention immediately is a vital part of storytelling. In this podcast we explore techniques to make sure your writing grabs the reader right from the first sentence.

item.title: Episode 7 - What the rejection letter doesn't tell you
item.description: In this podcast I explore some of the mistakes that editors look out for. Here are ten things to think about before you submit your work - get them right and make your manuscript shine!
item.dc:creator: Andrew J Chamberlain

item.title: Episode 6 - The serious business of writing something funny
item.description: This is the last of the five techniques for showing not telling - and arguably it's the hardest one to do. Humour is a serious business and requires precision and integrity in its execution. Precision in terms of timing and editing, and integrity in terms of keeping the characters and scene believable.
item.dc:creator: Andrew J Chamberlain
item.itunes:summary: This is the last of the five techniques for showing not telling - and arguably it's the hardest one to do. Humour is a serious business and requires precision and integrity in its execution. Precision in terms of timing and editing, and integrity in terms of keeping the characters and scene believable.
item.itunes:subtitle: This is the last of the five techniques for showing not telling - and arguably it's the hardest o...

item.title: Episode 5 - The power of suggestion
item.description: In this episode we look at another dimension of showing not telling, and that's the potential for hinting, suggesting or implying something rather than telling the reader outright. One of the most powerful tools we have as creative writers is derived from the fact that a hint or suggestion, well understood, will always have more power than something said explicitly.
item.dc:creator: Andrew J Chamberlain

item.title: Episode 4 - The zest of the orange, the icy tingle of the stream in winter
item.description: In this episode I will explain how you can use sensory language to show rather than tell your story

item.description: How to use a small number of very specific descriptive cues to show your reader both scene and character

item.title: Episode 2 - Dialogue
item.description: Practical, accessible advice on using dialogue in your creative writing to develop character, build tension and progress the plot of your story.
